Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Cosmic Evolution of Dense Gas in Star-Forming Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last several years large observational programs have produced results that have led to a basic understanding of how star formation in galaxies has evolved over cosmic time. However, an understanding of why star formation varies as it does has remained elusive. This is primarily due to a lack of information about the dense reservoirs of gas that serve as the fuel of star formation in these galaxies. In this proposal Dr. Baker outlines a program to characterize the masses, distributions, and physical conditions of the dense gas in a range of star-forming galaxies. The core strategy of the program is to target distant (high-redshift) galaxies that have been gravitationally lensed by foreground galaxy clusters. This proposal will use the NSF-funded ALMA array to make critical observations for the program.

This proposal will support one graduate and one undergraduate for the duration of the grant. The undergraduates will be participate in the Research in Science and Engineering (RISE) program at Rutgers University, a program specially aimed at underrepresented groups and/or first-generation college students. Additional educational activities, such as the inclusion of modern astronomy topics in physics classes, will take place as part of an existing collaboration between Dr. Baker and Xavier University in New Orleans and a majority-minority high school in Newark, New Jersey. The materials developed through this grant will also be incorporated into the Rutgers Future Scholars program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how galaxies formed and evolved over cosmic time is a central goal of modern astrophysics. An important step towards this goal is characterizing the detailed properties (masses, distributions, and physical conditions) of the clouds of interstellar gas and dust from which galaxies' new stars are formed. Observations of the gas and dust in galaxies at early cosmic epochs (i.e., high redshifts) are especially challenging, since their great distances make these galaxies appear small and faint on the sky. The principal investigator (PI) for this project and his students aimed to meet this challenge using two approaches: taking advantage of gravitational lensing by foreground galaxies and galaxy clusters, which can stretch and magnify the light from background galaxies, and studying the rare nearby analogs of important high-redshift galaxy populations. During the course of the project, the massive galaxy clusters that initially served only as signposts for finding lensed high-redshift galaxies also emerged as objects worthy of detailed study in their own right.

The 20 refereed papers published as part of this project have reported results that include the following:

  • High-redshift galaxies are forming stars from their interstellar gas reservoirs more efficiently (per unit area) than spiral galaxies in the local universe (Sharon et al. 2013; Sharon et al. 2019).
  • Dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs)-- an important category of galaxies so thoroughly enshrouded by interstellar dust that they can be nearly invisible at optical wavelengths-- can be found out to very high redshifts and very early cosmic times (Su et al. 2017; Aguirre et al. 2018). Detailed studies of the gas in individual DSFGs for this project have revealed evidence for galaxy merging (Sharon et al. 2015), outflows driven by central supermassive black holes (Roberts-Borsani et al. 2017), and unusual physical conditions (Rivera et al. 2019) within the population.
  • Robust models for the effects of gravitational lensing that reconstruct how "delensed" sources would look in the absence of lensing can be strongly (Sharon et al. 2019) or entirely (Rivera et al. 2019) informed by maps of the emission from a galaxy's interstellar gas at different line-of-sight velocities (i.e., slightly different observed frequencies). The images provided with this report, from Rivera et al. (2019), use color-coding to represent gas moving at different line-of-sight velocities within the DSFG ACT-S J020941+001557. (The name of this galaxy reflects its discovery by the Atacama Cosmology Telescope and its location on the sky.) Once the observed maps have been "delensed," the galaxy is revealed to have internal motions consistent with expectation for a rotating gas disk.
  • The rare local analogs of high-redshift Lyman break galaxies have interstellar gas with properties that are extreme (low temperature, high density, high thermal pressure) compared to those of local spiral galaxies (Contursi et al. 2017), and have gas kinematics and energetics that reflect strong "feedback" (i.e., the injection of energy and momentum) from young, massive stars (Wu et al. 2019).
  • Massive high-redshift galaxy clusters-- in particular, as identified by the Atacama Cosmology Telescope in silhouette against the cosmic microwave background due to the Sunyav-Zel'dovich effect (SZE)-- exhibit unique scaling relations between their SZE signals and the masses of the stars in their galaxies (Hilton et al. 2013). These clusters exhibit an unexpectedly high prevalence of diffuse radio emission, often indicative of a history of merging (Knowles et al. 2019), including a giant radio halo in an unusually low-mass cluster (Knowles et al. 2016) and the highest-redshift radio "relic" and halo system ever discovered (Lindner et al. 2014). For six systems, detailed observations of SZE signals enabled measurements of the clusters' motions relative to the cosmic microwave background (Lindner et al. 2015). For four systems, a detailed study of the properties of the galaxies in the clusters (informed by observations with ALMA, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array) revealed an increasingly high fraction of dusty systems at higher redshifts (Wu et al. 2018).

The broader impacts of this project have included the research training of seven undergraduate and six graduate student researchers at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. Four of the seven undergraduates came from institutions other than Rutgers, and participated in the university's Research Intensive Summer Experience (RISE) and/or Physics and Astronomy Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) programs. Six of the seven undergraduates have gone on to pursue graduate degrees in astronomy, physics, and statistics; five of the six graduate students earned their Ph.D.s over the course of the project and have secured jobs in academia and data science, with one still in graduate school as of August 2019. Overall, six of the thirteen students supported by the project are members of groups that are underrepresented in the physical sciences. The project's original goal of strengthening contacts with physics departments at multiple minority-serving institutions has been achieved via repeated in-person visits by the PI over the course of several years.
